thread.title: John Lewis and Waitrose profits slump 99 per cent

author: Tom Pegden
title: John Lewis and Waitrose profits slump 99 per cent
text:
News John Lewis and Waitrose profits slump 99 per cent Group, with landmark store in Highcross Leicester, saw profits of just £1.2m in the first six months of year Share Get Business updates directly to your inbox Subscribe Thank you for subscribing See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
Profits at John Lewis Partnership and Waitrose have slumped almost 99 per cent this year due to tough conditions on the high street and shoppers taking advantage of its policy to price match competitors.
The group - which has a landmark store in Leicester's Highcross - reported profits of just £1.2 million in the first six months of the year.
That compares to a profit of £83 million in the same period last year.
The business warned that its eventual full-year profits would also be substantially down.
It said profits at John Lewis & Partners have continued to be squeezed by strong competition as it moves to keep prices low despite inflation, and has offered "unprecedented" levels of price-matching through its Never Knowingly Undersold pledge.
Earlier this week it was reported that the firm had paid Sir Elton John £5 million to feature in this year's Christmas advert. John Lewis in Highcross, Leicester
And in March it was revealed the annual bonus - paid to all staff at the firm - was just five per cent, the lowest figure since 1954.
There are Waitrose stores in Oadby, Blaby, Mountsorrel and Lutterworth and at the Leicester Forest East Services on the M1.
Sir Charlie Mayfield, chairman of the John Lewis Partnership, said: "These are challenging times in retail."
He said the group was seeing the "most promotional market we've seen in almost a decade", with other retailers discounting heavily.
He warned: "With the level of uncertainty facing consumers and the economy, in part due to ongoing Brexit negotiations, forecasting is particularly difficult but we continue to expect full-year profits to be substantially lower than last year for the Partnership as a whole."
The business - which recently rolled out the '& Partners' rebrand across the group - had warned about expected profits at a strategy update in June, when it also said it would shut another four Waitrose convenience shops and a small supermarket, affecting around 200 staff.
John Lewis department stores slumped to an underling operating loss of £19.2 million. John Lewis in Highcross, Leicester
This offset a better performance at Waitrose, which remained in profit, albeit down 12.2 per cent at £96.4 million on an underlying basis.
Sir Charlie said the group expects profit growth in Waitrose to continue to be offset by the squeeze at John Lewis.
But he pledged to continue with plans to invest in the group - at a rate of £400 million to £500 million a year - despite the pressures on its profits to drive long-term growth. Read More
He said: "This will take a lot of hard work from all of our partners, but we are confident in our commitment, drive and ability to deliver the partnership's strategy." Read More
The department store sector has faced a turbulent few months.
House of Fraser was sold to Sports Direct in the summer.
While Debenhams , which has just revamped its Highcross store and is still in talks with the owner of Fosse Park to build a new store there, has brought in advisers from KPMG to help turn around the business. Like us on Facebook
